natural problem: There are finitely many primes $p$ for which the congruence $$8x\equiv 1\pmod{p}$$has no solutions $x$. Determine the sum of all such $p$.
natural solution: A solution exists if and only if $8$ is invertible modulo $p$. In other words, $\gcd(8,p)=1$. Since $8=2^3$ is a power of $2$, $8$ is invertible modulo $q$ if and only if $q$ is an odd integer. All primes except for $2$ are odd, so the number we are looking for is $\boxed{2}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p x :: int
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "\<not> (\<exists> x. [8 * x = 1] (mod p))"
shows  "p = 2"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There are finitely many primes $p$ for which the congruence $$8x\equiv 1\pmod{p}$$has no solutions $x$. Determine the sum of all such $p$. The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 A solution exists if and only if $8$ is invertible modulo $p$. In other words, $\gcd(8,p)=1$. Since $8=2^3$ is a power of $2$, $8$ is invertible modulo $q$ if and only if $q$ is an odd integer. All primes except for $2$ are odd, so the number we are looking for is $\boxed{2}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p x :: int
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "\<not> (\<exists> x. [8 * x = 1] (mod p))"
shows  "p = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find a prime number $p$ such that there is no integer $x$ satisfying the congruence $8x \equiv 1 \mod p$. The final answer is $2$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p x :: int and S :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "finite S"
and h1 : "\<forall> p. p \<in> S \<longrightarrow> is_prime p \<and> (\<forall> x. x mod p \<noteq> 1 / 8)"
shows  "setsum id S = 2"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There are finitely many primes $p$ for which the congruence $$8x\equiv 1\pmod{p}$$has no solutions $x$. Determine the sum of all such $p$. The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 A solution exists if and only if $8$ is invertible modulo $p$. In other words, $\gcd(8,p)=1$. Since $8=2^3$ is a power of $2$, $8$ is invertible modulo $q$ if and only if $q$ is an odd integer. All primes except for $2$ are odd, so the number we are looking for is $\boxed{2}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p x :: int and S :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "finite S"
and h1 : "\<forall> p. p \<in> S \<longrightarrow> is_prime p \<and> (\<forall> x. x mod p \<noteq> 1 / 8)"
shows  "setsum id S = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Consider a finite set of integers, S. Each integer in S is a prime number and for every integer x, x modulo any integer in S is not equal to 1/8. What is the sum of all integers in S? The final answer is 2.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: nat and x :: nat
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "\<not>(\<exists>x. [8 * x = 1] (mod p))"
shows  "p = 2"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There are finitely many primes $p$ for which the congruence $$8x\equiv 1\pmod{p}$$has no solutions $x$. Determine the sum of all such $p$. The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 A solution exists if and only if $8$ is invertible modulo $p$. In other words, $\gcd(8,p)=1$. Since $8=2^3$ is a power of $2$, $8$ is invertible modulo $q$ if and only if $q$ is an odd integer. All primes except for $2$ are odd, so the number we are looking for is $\boxed{2}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: nat and x :: nat
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "\<not>(\<exists>x. [8 * x = 1] (mod p))"
shows  "p = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find a prime number $p$ such that there is no natural number $x$ for which $8x$ is congruent to $1$ modulo $p$. The final answer is $p = 2$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x p :: int
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. [8 * x \<noteq> 1] (mod p)"
shows  "sum_list (filter (\<lambda>p. prime p \<and> \<forall>x. [8 * x \<noteq> 1] (mod p)) [2..]) = 2"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There are finitely many primes $p$ for which the congruence $$8x\equiv 1\pmod{p}$$has no solutions $x$. Determine the sum of all such $p$. The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 A solution exists if and only if $8$ is invertible modulo $p$. In other words, $\gcd(8,p)=1$. Since $8=2^3$ is a power of $2$, $8$ is invertible modulo $q$ if and only if $q$ is an odd integer. All primes except for $2$ are odd, so the number we are looking for is $\boxed{2}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x p :: int
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. [8 * x \<noteq> 1] (mod p)"
shows  "sum_list (filter (\<lambda>p. prime p \<and> \<forall>x. [8 * x \<noteq> 1] (mod p)) [2..]) = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the sum of all prime numbers $p$ that satisfy the condition that for all integers $x$, $8x$ is not congruent to $1$ modulo $p$. The final answer is $2$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p x :: int
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "\<not> (\<exists> x. [8 * x = 1] (mod p))"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> p. if prime p \<and> \<not> (\<exists> x. [8 * x = 1] (mod p)) then p else 0) {2..} = 2"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There are finitely many primes $p$ for which the congruence $$8x\equiv 1\pmod{p}$$has no solutions $x$. Determine the sum of all such $p$. The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 A solution exists if and only if $8$ is invertible modulo $p$. In other words, $\gcd(8,p)=1$. Since $8=2^3$ is a power of $2$, $8$ is invertible modulo $q$ if and only if $q$ is an odd integer. All primes except for $2$ are odd, so the number we are looking for is $\boxed{2}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p x :: int
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "\<not> (\<exists> x. [8 * x = 1] (mod p))"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> p. if prime p \<and> \<not> (\<exists> x. [8 * x = 1] (mod p)) then p else 0) {2..} = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the sum of all prime numbers $p$ where there does not exist an integer $x$ such that $8x \equiv 1 \mod p$. The final answer is $2$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p x :: int and S :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "S = {p. prime p \<and> (\<nexists>x. [8 * x = 1] (mod p))}"
shows  "sum id S = 2"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There are finitely many primes $p$ for which the congruence $$8x\equiv 1\pmod{p}$$has no solutions $x$. Determine the sum of all such $p$. The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 A solution exists if and only if $8$ is invertible modulo $p$. In other words, $\gcd(8,p)=1$. Since $8=2^3$ is a power of $2$, $8$ is invertible modulo $q$ if and only if $q$ is an odd integer. All primes except for $2$ are odd, so the number we are looking for is $\boxed{2}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p x :: int and S :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "S = {p. prime p \<and> (\<nexists>x. [8 * x = 1] (mod p))}"
shows  "sum id S = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find the sum of all prime numbers $p$ for which there is no integer $x$ such that $8x \equiv 1 \mod p$. The sum of these primes is $2$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x p :: nat and f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat set"
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "f p = {x. [8 * x = 1] (mod p)}"
and h2 : "f p = {}"
shows  "\<Sum>p\<in>{p. prime p \<and> f p = {}}. p = 2"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There are finitely many primes $p$ for which the congruence $$8x\equiv 1\pmod{p}$$has no solutions $x$. Determine the sum of all such $p$. The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 A solution exists if and only if $8$ is invertible modulo $p$. In other words, $\gcd(8,p)=1$. Since $8=2^3$ is a power of $2$, $8$ is invertible modulo $q$ if and only if $q$ is an odd integer. All primes except for $2$ are odd, so the number we are looking for is $\boxed{2}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x p :: nat and f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat set"
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "f p = {x. [8 * x = 1] (mod p)}"
and h2 : "f p = {}"
shows  "\<Sum>p\<in>{p. prime p \<and> f p = {}}. p = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Let p be a prime number, and let f(p) be the set of natural numbers x such that 8x is congruent to 1 modulo p. If the set f(p) is empty, find the sum of such prime numbers p. The final answer is 2.
